s.text: No one has accused Thomas of trying to silence Hill.
10 Lying: Defenders of both men have argued that, even if true, the behavior they stand accused of is harmless.
Their credibility depends on corroboration by people who claim they were told of the harassment soon after it occurred.
The relationship it describes may strike many as exploitative or ugly for other reasons, but it is not illegal.
While right-wing and left-wing groups have helped trumpet the two women's causes, nobody has shown convincingly that either side trumped up the accusations.
While right-wing and left-wing groups have helped trumpet the two women's causes, nobody has shown convincingly that either side trumped up the accusations.

According to the Supreme Court's interpretation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964--the basis for most harassment cases--harassment is actionable when it is "sufficiently severe and pervasive to ...
b) Courts rarely consider a one-time instance of harassment "severe and pervasive."

Thomas may have talked about porn films, asked Hill out on patently unwelcome dates, bragged about his sexual prowess, and referred to pubic hairs on Coke cans, but Hill says that Thomas never flashed his genitals, touched her sexually, or propositioned her explicitly.

Thomas may have talked about porn films, asked Hill out on patently unwelcome dates, bragged about his sexual prowess, and referred to pubic hairs on Coke cans, but Hill says that Thomas never flashed his genitals, touched her sexually, or propositioned her explicitly.

Some Clinton defenders argue that the voters knew about the president's alleged proclivities, if they didn't know the details of any particular case, and implicitly accepted them when they elected him twice.
By contrast, Thomas failed to pick up on Hill's lack of interest, her repeated assertions that she didn't want to date Thomas and her "obvious discomfort" with his "wild talk."
The Los Angeles Times has reported that Clinton asked Ferguson not to testify about the encounter with Jones.
